data.title: European Network Remembrance and Solidarity
data.meta_description: European Network Remembrance and Solidarity | 347  obserwujƒÖcych na LinkedIn. We foster a common European culture of remembrance and dialogue on difficult issues of 20th-century European history | The European Network Remembrance and Solidarity is an international initiative whose aim is to foster international discourse on history and remembrance, with particular emphasis on periods of dictatorships, wars and resistance to political violence. The members of the Network are Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania and Slovakia, with representatives from Albania, Austria, the Czech Republic,‚ÄØEstonia,‚ÄØGeorgia,‚ÄØLatvia and‚ÄØLithuania‚ÄØpresent on its advisory bodies. Envisaged as an ever-developing project, the Network‚Äôs activities go beyond the member countries, expanding the area of dialogue about 20th-century history further afield across Europe.
data.text:
üì¢ Engage with Museums: Protest as Participation We are delighted to share that the discussions from this year‚Äôs European Remembrance Symposium continue to resonate, in Lithuanian National Television and Radio LRT portal! üîé Estonian museum researcher Pille Pruulmann-Vengerfeldt's thought-provoking ideas still spark conversations on the true meaning of engagement with museums. According to Pruulmann-Vengerfeldt, the most authentic involvement comes through conscious protest against exhibits that feel unacceptable, alien, or unnecessary. üìç Held at the Polish History Museum in Warsaw (Muzeum Historii Polski w Warszawie), this year's symposium brought together museum professionals, historians, and politicians to explore the concept of freedom in today's world. Pruulmann-Vengerfeldt, with her extensive research in cultural citizenship and participation, challenged us to rethink our interactions with museums. üí° She emphasized that museums must become more accessible and relevant to the public, inviting diverse voices and even welcoming dissent to stay meaningful and dynamic. ‚û° Read the full intreview to delve into these ideas and more. Join the conversation and rethink how you interact with museums: https://lnkd.in/dRx8ixmt #EuropeanRemembrance #EuropeanRemembranceSymposium #Museums #CitizenParticipation

üì£ Reminder: Call for Abstracts Closes on July 31st! Don't miss your chance to submit abstracts for the 23rd International Oral History Association Conference, themed 'Re-Thinking Oral History'! üóìÔ∏è Deadline: July 31, 2024 üìç Conference Dates: September 17-19, 2025 üìç Location: Krakow, Poland Submit your abstracts in English through the online form on the organizer‚Äôs website. The IOHA conferences, held biennially, are a global gathering for researchers, practitioners, and anyone interested in oral history. This upcoming edition is organized by the Polish Oral History Society (Polskie Towarzystwo Historii M√≥wionej), alongside the European Network Remembrance and Solidarity, the Faculty of History at Jagiellonian University, and the Zajezdnia History Centre (Centrum Historii Zajezdnia). In conjunction with the conference, we also recommend the publication, 'The Voice of the Past: Oral History' by Paul Thompson and Joanna Bornat, an essential read for those engaged in the field of oral history. üìö More about the book: https://bit.ly/3LL2zTO üåê More about the conference: https://bit.ly/4cYpd77 Ensure your voice is part of this significant dialogue on oral history. Submit your abstracts now! #OralHistory #IOHA2025 #CallForPapers #HistoryConference #Research #Krakow2025 #SubmitYourAbstracts #OralHistorySociety #Historiography #AcademicConference

üèÜ On 27 July 1924, at the VIII Summer Olympics in Paris, the Polish track cycling team, J√≥zef Lange, Jan Lazarski, Tomasz Stankiewicz and Franciszek Szymczyk, triumphantly won a silver medal. On the same day, Adam Kr√≥likiewicz, riding Picador, clinched the bronze in show jumping. These victories marked Poland‚Äôs first Olympic medals. ‚≠ê Commemorating the 100th anniversary of this momentous achievement, the Sejm has declared 2024 the Year of Polish Olympians. However, the stories of Polish Olympic athletes throughout the 20th century encompass not only glory but also enslavement and resistance against oppressive regimes. üìë Our article, 'Olympian Values in Peace and War', explores the compelling stories of these athletes throughout the 20th century. From their promising beginnings to the harrowing experiences during World War II, many Polish Olympians faced imprisonment, forced labor, and participation in resistance movements. Despite these challenges, their commitment to the Olympic ideals and the spirit of sport endured, even within the confines of POW camps. üíõ Their legacy of perseverance, patriotism, and dedication continues to inspire future generations. üîó Read the full article and discover the fate of these remarkable athletes #OlympicLegacy #PolishOlympians #YearOfPolishOlympians #Resilience #History #SportsInspiratio #Remembrance

üñ§ Honoring the Victims of Totalitarian Regimes with 'Remember. August 23' Campaign üí¨ The campaign pays tribute to the victims of totalitarian regimes, marking the European Day of Remembrance for Victims of Totalitarian Regimes, proclaimed by the European Parliament on the anniversary of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. This agreement between Nazism and Communism led to the tragedy of nearly 80 million people. For the tenth time, the European Network Remembrance and Solidarity (ENRS) underscores the importance of these historical events. üìñ Signed in August 1939, the German-Soviet Pact paved the way for World War II and its dire consequences: mass deportations, exterminations, slave labor, war crimes, the Holocaust, and ethnic cleansing. For many European societies, it meant years of enslavement and profound losses. üì¢ The ‚ÄòRemember. August 23' campaign aims to make August 23rd a symbol of remembrance and deepen the understanding of the struggles faced by those who lived under totalitarian regimes. üìç This Year's Campaign Highlights ‚û° Short film spots: dedicated to individuals whose lives were marked by dramatic struggles against totalitarian systems. ‚û° Commemorative pins: a symbolic gesture of remembrance. ‚û° Media and outdoor campaigns: in selected European capitals, including posters with profiles of selected protagonists. ‚û° Articles: discussing contemporary controversies surrounding the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. ‚û° Guide to the Commemoration of 23 August: available on www.enrs.eu. ‚û° Mural unveiling: A unique visualisation of intergenerational memory at 5 Lipowa Street, near the University of Warsaw. ‚ú® This year‚Äôs campaign heroes include: ‚û° Johann Trollmann (1907‚Äì1944): a German boxer of Roma origin, a victim of Nazi persecution, murdered by kapo whom he had previously defeated in the ring. ‚û° Em√≠lie Mach√°lkov√° (1926‚Äì2017): a Czech woman of Roma origin, Holocaust survivor and promoter of Roma culture. Previous years have honored figures such as: W≈Çadys≈Çaw Bartoszewski, Boris Romanchenko, Doina Cornea, Ieva Lase, Jaan Kross, Kazimierz Moczarski, Milada Hor√°kov√°, Juliana Zarchi, Mala Zimetbaum and Edek Gali≈Ñski, and P√©ter Mansfeld. ‚ùì How to join The ENRS has prepared several ways to commemorate the European Day of Remembrance for Victims of Totalitarian Regimes: ‚û° Wear a pin: share this gesture of remembrance online. ‚û° Post a photo: with the ENRS pin and use hashtags hashtag #RememberAugust23, hashtag #ENRS. ‚û° Share reflections: on the mural or on individual stories of those who experienced totalitarian violence. ‚û° Read articles: by Stefan Troebst, Roger Moorhouse and. Prof. Jan Rydel. ‚û° Use educational resources: available on https://lnkd.in/dNpJANth. ‚û° Visit memorials: dedicated to victims of totalitarian regimes and share your reflections. ‚û° Commemorate with others: and stay engaged. Learn more about the ENRS‚Äôs commemoration efforts here: https://bit.ly/3Wmuv5j

The official opening of ‚ÄòAfter the Great War‚Äô outdoor exhibition took place last Friday in Bad Ischl, Austria. The event was attended by honoured guests, including Ines Schiller, the Mayor of Bad Ischl, Hannes Heide Member of the European Parliament, Radu-Dumitru Florea Consul General of Romania in Salzburg and Sead Novkiniƒá, Consul of Bosnia and Hercegovina in Salzburg. Dr Hannes Leidinger from the University of Vienna provided an introductory lecture and Professor Jan Rydel (ENRS) invited the audience to a tour of the exhibition. We would like to thank MEP Hannes Heide and his team for their support and great cooperation which made the exhibition in Bad Isch possible. Photos: Chris G√ºtl The exhibition in Bad Ischl will be available until 20 August. More information: https://lnkd.in/dAY-yycH Exhibition catalogue: https://lnkd.in/dYi4h-i8

üì¢ We are grateful for the opportunity to join the European Network Remembrance and Solidarity as a partner for the International Conference: ‚Äò80 Years After the Destruction of the Kaunas Ghetto ‚Äì What Do We Remember, What Have We Learnt?‚Äô organized by the Kauno IX forto muziejus | The Ninth Fort. üîé The conference aimed to examine the history of the Kaunas Ghetto and the broader lessons of the Holocaust in Lithuania and other Nazi-occupied countries. Experts from Lithuania, Poland, Germany, the USA, Ukraine, and Israel gathered to discuss and reflect on these critical issues. ü§ù We are delighted that Deputy Director Iga Raczy≈Ñska and Head of the Academic Department Dr. Malgorzata Pakier were able to actively participate on behalf of the ENRS in the conference, what underscore the importance of remembering and learning from these tragic historical events. *** üìï In the summer of 1944, as the front lines approached Kaunas, it was decided to finally liquidate the Jewish ghetto. In early July, deportations from the ghetto to concentration camps in Nazi Germany began. Some inhabitants tried to survive the Nazi retreat by hiding in pre-arranged hideouts, known as malinas. However, before their departure, the Gestapo set fire to the ghetto houses, shooting those attempting to escape. The fires burned throughout July. Sara Ginaitƒó-Rubinsonienƒó, a member of the Kaunas Jewish Ghetto underground, recalls: üí≠ ‚ÄòThe ghetto was shrouded in smoke, through which the chimneys of the burnt-out houses were visible as if through a mist. For almost three weeks, the houses of Kaunas Ghetto were burning, the people who were hiding in them were burning, and the ground was burning... The corpses of charred people, household utensils, bedding, and photographs scattered by the wind could be seen around every house. Only the stone fence posts were intact.‚Äô *** ü§ù We extend our heartfelt thanks to everyone involved for organizing and participating in this significant event. üìç This project is funded by the LR kult≈´ros ministerija / LR Ministry of Culture Information partner ‚Äì 'Kauno Diena' Partners: European Network Remembrance And Solidarity, ENRS, International Commission for the Evaluation of the Crimes of the Nazi and Soviet Occupation Regimes in Lithuania ‚û° Conference patrons: Ambassador of Israel to Lithuania Hadas Wittenberg Silverstein German Ambassador to Lithuania Dr. Cornelius Zimmermann üì∑ Andrius Fioklinas #conference #konferencija #KaunasGhetto #remembrance

üîî The second day of the internatioal conference '80 Years After the Destruction of the Kaunas Ghetto ‚Äì What Do We Remember, What Have We Learnt?' has just started. Today's programme will concern the fates affected by the Holocaust and a closing discussion. üìã ùêèùêëùêéùêÜùêëùêÄùêåùêåùêÑ ùêÖùêéùêë ùêâùêîùêãùêò ùüèùüñ 3Ô∏è‚É£ ùêèùêÄùêëùêì ùêàùêàùêà: ùêÖùêÄùêìùêÑùêí ùêÄùêÖùêÖùêÑùêÇùêìùêÑùêÉ ùêÅùêò ùêìùêáùêÑ ùêáùêéùêãùêéùêÇùêÄùêîùêíùêì üé§ Moderated by Head of the Media and Democracy Programme, Vilnius Institute for Policy Analysis Donatas Puslys ùüó:ùüéùüé‚Äìùüó:ùüëùüé Arrival of participants ùüó:ùüëùüé‚Äìùüèùüé:ùüéùüé 'Vu ahin zol ikh geyn' ['Where shall I go']: The Fates of Postwar ≈†iauliai Jews Dr. Vadim Altskan, United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, U.S.A. ùüèùüé:ùüéùüé‚Äìùüèùüé:ùüëùüé 'Few Days Were Left for Us' ‚Äì German-speaking Jews after Deportation to the Occupied Baltic States Dr. Andrea L√∂w, Centre for Holocaust Studies, Leibniz Institute for Contemporary History - Institut f√ºr Zeitgeschichte in Munich, Deutschland ùüèùüé:ùüëùüé‚Äìùüèùüè:ùüéùüé Coffee break ùüèùüè:ùüéùüé‚Äìùüèùüè:ùüëùüé 'Who can remain indifferent to such images ‚Äì worse than in Nero's time...' ‚Äì Analysis of non-Jewish reactions to anti-Jewish policies in former soviet territories ‚Äì the case of the Crimean Peninsula Masha Pollak-Rozenberg, Yad Vashem, Israel ùüèùüè:ùüëùüé‚Äìùüèùüê:ùüéùüé The prosecution of World War II criminals in the United States: The Case of the Lithuanian Diaspora Dr. Justas Stoncius, Klaipeda University, Lithuania ùüèùüê:ùüéùüé‚Äìùüèùüê:ùüëùüé Information about the Holocaust in Kaunas in the Soviet Lithuania newspaper 1944-1945. Dr. Modestas Kuodys, Kauno IX forto muziejus | The Ninth Fort, Lithuania ùüèùüê:ùüëùüé‚Äìùüèùüë:ùüëùüé Lunch break (lunch self-sufficient) 4Ô∏è‚É£ ùêÇùêãùêéùêíùêàùêçùêÜ ùêèùêÄùêëùêì üé§ Moderated by Marius Peƒçiulis, Director of Kaunas Ninth Fort Museum, and Vytautas Petrikƒónas, Historian ùüèùüë:ùüëùüé‚Äìùüèùüí:ùüëùüé Discussion, summary and closing of the conference üìç This project is funded by the LR kult≈´ros ministerija / LR Ministry of Culture The conference is organised by the Kaunas Ninth Fort Museum Information partner ‚Äì 'Kauno Diena' ü§ù Partners: European Network Remembrance And Solidarity, ENRS, International Commission for the Evaluation of the Crimes of the Nazi and Soviet Occupation Regimes in Lithuania ‚û° Conference patrons: Ambassador of Israel to Lithuania Hadas Wittenberg Silverstein German Ambassador to Lithuania Dr. Cornelius Zimmermann #conference #konferencija #KaunasGhetto #remembrance

‚ùó üóìÔ∏è It is already today the international conference: '80 Years After the Destruction of the Kaunas Ghetto ‚Äì What Do We Remember, What Have We Learnt?' starts in Kaunas! The conference will delve into the historical memory and the lives affected by the Holocaust. üìÖ PROGRAMME FOR JULY 17: 9:30‚Äì10:00: Arrival of participants / Welcome coffee 10:00‚Äì10:30: Welcome speeches by: Marius Peƒçiulis, Director of Kauno IX forto muziejus | The Ninth Fort Representative from the Israeli Embassy in Lithuania Representative from the German Embassy in Lithuania / Vokietijos Federacinƒós Respublikos ambasada 1Ô∏è‚É£ PART I: KAUNAS GHETTO: MEMORY AND PEOPLE üé§ Moderated by Vytautas Bruveris, Editor-in-Chief, ELTA News Agency 10:30‚Äì11:00: Problems of Understanding the History of the Kaunas Ghetto - Dr. Nerijus ≈†epetys, Vilniaus universitetas / Vilnius University 11:00‚Äì11:30: Visual Representations of Everyday Life in the Kaunas Ghetto: Reality and Memory - Prof. Dr. (HP) Giedre Jankeviciute, Vilniaus dailƒós akademija | Vilnius Academy of Arts 11:30‚Äì12:00: Coffee Break 12:00‚Äì12:30: Zvi George Kadish ‚Äì Kaunas Resident, Kaunas Ghetto Chronicler - Dr. Linas Venclauskas, Vytautas Magnus University / Vytauto Did≈æiojo universitetas 12:30‚Äì13:00: Kaunas Ghetto Jews in Stutthof Concentration Camp in 1944-1945 - Dr. Ar≈´nas Bubnys, Lithuanian Genocide and Resistance Research Centre / Lietuvos gyventoj≈≥ genocido ir rezistencijos tyrimo centras 13:00‚Äì14:00: Lunch Break (self-sufficient) 2Ô∏è‚É£ PART II: HISTORICAL MEMORY OF THE HOLOCAUST üé§ Moderated by Rimas Bru≈æas, Journalist and Documentary Filmmaker 14:00‚Äì14:30: The Holocaust in Lithuanian Memory Culture - Prof. Alvydas Nik≈æentaitis, Lithuanian Historical Institute 14:30‚Äì15:00: Holocaust History Education: Traditional Models and/or New Possibilities - Dr. Hektoras Vitkus, Klaipeda University 15:00‚Äì15:30: Holocaust Remembrance in Poland [remote presentation] - Dr. Malgorzata Pakier, European Network of Remembrance and Solidarity 15:30‚Äì16:00: Babyn Yar after Bucza: The Russian-Ukrainian War and Holocaust Memory in Ukraine [remote presentation] - Dr. Yana Prymachenko, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine 16:00‚Äì17:00: Discussion and Conclusion of Day One ‚û° This project is funded by the Ministry of Culture of the Republic of Lithuania LR kult≈´ros ministerija / LR Ministry of Culture and organized by the Kaunas Ninth Fort Museum. Information partner: 'Kauno Diena.' Partners: European Network Remembrance And Solidarity (ENRS), and the International Commission for the Evaluation of the Crimes of the Nazi and Soviet Occupation Regimes in Lithuania. ‚û° Conference Patrons: Ambassador of Israel to Lithuania, Hadas Wittenberg Silverstein German Ambassador to Lithuania, Dr. Cornelius Zimmermann Don't miss out on this insightful event! üôå #conference #KaunasGhetto #historicalmemory #Holocaust #remembrance

üì£ Exciting news for Bad Ischl and all visitors! üîé In two days we will open our outdoor exhibition 'After the Great War: New Europe 1918-1923.' This will be the exhibition's second stop in Austria, following its display in Vienna during the summer of 2021. ‚≠êÔ∏è üåç Over 200 archive and multimedia materials ‚Äì pictures, maps, and films ‚Äì together with individual stories of those who lived then, present a complex yet coherent picture of a New Europe. The main goal of the travelling display is to illustrate the scale of the political changes and their impact on current politics as well as to reveal different national memories. üí¨ The primary aim of curating this traveling exhibition was to highlight the extensive political changes and their enduring effects on current politics, as well as to showcase various national memories. Many of these historical changes continue to shape Europe today. üí° üìç Visit the exhibition at Bertha-von-Suttner Platz from 19 July to 20 August. It's open 24/7, and entry is free. üîó Find out more here: https://lnkd.in/esyHxXGV üì∑ Photos from the exhibition in Sibiu, Romania by Cristian Bota. Partners: Stadt Bad Ischl, Hannes Heide We can't wait to welcome you! üôå
